Mr Luettgen apparently doesn't read Dr. Krugman, much. Krugman has actively campaigned for a return to normal inflation, since he is no fan of zero inflation and zero interest rates -- the infamous zero lower bound. Underinflation is not only bad for some parts of the population (people living on bond income, for example, or pension planners) but also because the zero lower bound robs central bankers of their best stimulus tool.

But the inflation cultists that Krugman's writing about haven't been shouting from the rooftops that inflation might return to 3% a year. They keep saying -- in the face of relentless evidence -- that hyperinflation, or even the complete collapse of our currency a la Zimbabwe is just around the corner. This will happen, they say, because the US is just like Greece, profligately overspending -- even though Greece for the past 5 years has been suffering from ongoing severe DEflation. (As both of these hyperbolic claims suggest, attention to evidence has never been among the strong points of inflation cultists.)

Nevertheless, not only Murdoch's Journal but even the Times keeps publishing op-ed after op-ed by inflation cultists telling us that monetary collapse is on the threshold...really, this time! This, I think, is what puzzles Krugman. There are crazy apocalyptical thinkers in most major religions, so why shouldn't there be among market fundamentalists? But when Harold Camping predicted it for 2011, we just laughed.

Jefferson did order a naval squadron to confront the pirates but based on the Wikipedia entry it is uncertain whether it  establishes a clear, obvious precedent. 

Ships were sent but without a definite order to engage the pirates. (Unless necessary).

It states that because of pirate attacks & kidnappings "..Jefferson's cabinet voted unanimously to send three frigates and a schooner to the Mediterranean with orders to make a show of force but opt for peace; if a state of war existed they could use their own discretion. ...the squadron ...stopped at Gibraltar for supplies and information." There, the squadron commander "learned that Tripoli had already declared war upon the United States."
 
Jefferson subsequently "ordered five separate naval bombardments of Tripoli, which restored peace in the Mediterranean for a while".

@ http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_jefferson

Jefferson did not commit US forces to a war that would go on for years, possibly indefinitely.

The 1801 Tripoli precedent doesn't support your case. Before Jefferson's inauguration, Congress had passed a statute authorizing the use of force to destroy Barbary ships if one of those states declared war on the United States. After Tripoli did declare war, Jefferson sent a force to protect American shipping but refrained from offensive action until Congress authorized it.
http://www.loufisher.org/docs/wp/barbary.pdf

Cultural literacy isn't just about bad TV, and dopy after dentist YouTube videos. As an employee during the information age, I am a knowledge worker in communications, and cultural literacy is a requirement. Maybe I would have been an engineer or programmer if I had watched less TV and played fewer video games ...maybe.

I remember when I was a kid in the 1970s being fascinated by my grandfather's stories -- he had worked on a farm, had adventures, gone to dance school, performed in Vaudeville. I realized something was amiss when he spoke about his childhood. He had experiences and memories. I had watched TV. I did not have a cache of memories of real experiences, I had a head full of jingles and reruns.

When my kids were growing up in the '90s, we didn't have a TV. Other parents warned me that our kids would be Martians. They weren't -- kids are amazingly creative and resilient. At preschool my sons listened to their peers and memorized all of the Power Rangers colors and special powers. They faked the social literacy they needed enough to participate in the commercially-scripted play of their peers. Meanwhile, we started to get feedback from their teachers that our boys had more "background knowledge" than any other kids they knew. That's because they had a lot of time for experience, conversation, and reading, over screens.

Your children will cope if you set limits, and they will not be Martians. My sons chafed at the limits sometimes -- especially around video games like Halo, which their friends played nonstop -- but now in their twenties, they thank us frequently. They still have more background knowledge (and know how to do more with their hands, like play instruments) than anyone else they know. And they are adept at computers, because they are adults now.
